title: Man arrested for murder after 'warm, kind, generous' Leon Barrett-Hazle stabbed to death on Birmingham bus
text:
Leon Barrett-Hazle was allegedly stabbed multiple times (Photo: PA) Share Get daily   Thank you for subscribing!   
Police have charged a man with murder after a man was stabbed to death on board a Birmingham bus. 
Leon Barrett-Hazle was allegedly stabbed multiple times on the top deck of the 11A service in Rookery Road, Handsworth, at around on Monday, January 23. 
Paramedics battled to save the 36-year-old from Smethwick but he died at the scene. 
West Midlands Police confirmed tonight that Kieran Gillespie, from Wellesbourne Road in Handsworth, has been charged with murder over the attack. 
The 25-year-old will appear before magistrates in Birmingham on Friday morning. Detectives have arrested a 25-year-old man (Photo: BPM Media) 
In a statement released through West Midlands Police, Mr Barrett-Hazle’s family paid tribute to a “the best son, grandson, brother, nephew, cousin, 
uncle and friend anyone could ever wish for”. 
“Family and friends are devastated by the tragic loss of a wonderful, warm, 
kind, generous of heart and much-loved Leon Barrett Hazle,” the family said. 
“Words cannot express the immense grief and pain we are suffering but memories of your infectious smile, happy-go-lucky style will help fill the massive void in our lives. 
“You had so much life to live. No reason on earth can justify taking it away in such a manner. Rest in peace.” Investigating officers are still calling for witnesses (Photo: BPM Media) 
Police are still appealing for witnesses who were travelling on the bus at the time of the attack to come forward. 
Detective Inspector Warren Hines, from force CID, said: “We still need these witnesses to come forward to help us establish exactly what happened on the top deck of the 11A service on Monday evening in Rookery Road. 
“The family of the victim is being kept informed of the latest development in our investigation and our thoughts remain with them.” 
Det Insp Hines can be contacted on 101 or call Crimestoppers anonymously on 0800 555 111. Like us on Facebook
